Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You feeling any better?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: A little bit.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Guess what.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Your grandfather's here.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Mom, can't you tell him that I'm sick?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You are sick, that's why he's here.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: He'll pinch my cheek. I hate that.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Maybe he won't.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Hey! How's the sickie? Heh?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I think I'll leave you two pals.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: I brought you a special present.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Open it up.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: A book?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: That's right. When I was your age, television was called books. And this is a special book. It was the book my father used to read to me when I was sick, and I used to read it to your father. And today, I'm gonna read it to you.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Has it got any sports in it?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Are you kidding? Fencing. Fighting. Torture. Revenge. Giants. Monsters. Chases. Escapes. True love. Miracles.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: It doesn't sound too bad. I'll try and stay awake.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Oh. Well, thank you very much. It's very nice of you. Your vote of confidence is overwhelming. All right.  The Princess Bride, by S. Morgenstern. Chapter One. Buttercup was raised on a small farm in the country of Florin.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Isn't that a wonderful beginning?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Yeah. It's really good.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Nothing gave Buttercup as much pleasure as ordering Westley around.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Farm boy. Polish my horse's saddle. I want to see my face shining in it by morning.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: "As you wish" was all he ever said to her.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Farm Boy. Fill these with water --  --please.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: That day, she was amazed to discover that when he was saying, "As you wish," what he meant was, "I love you."

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: And even more amazing was the day she realized she truly loved him back.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Farm Boy, fetch me that pitcher.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -hold it, hold it-

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What is this? Are you trying to trick me? -- Where's the sports? -- Is this a kissing book?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: -- wait, just wait --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- well, when does it get good?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Keep your shirt on. Let me read.  Westley had no money for marriage. So he packed his few belongings and left the farm to seek his fortune across the sea.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: It was a very emotional time for Buttercup --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I don't be-leeve this.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I fear I'll never see you again.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Of course you will.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: But what if something happens to you?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Hear this now: I will come for you.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: But how can you be sure?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: This is true love. You think this happens every day?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Westley didn't reach his destination. His ship was attacked by the Dread Pirate Roberts, who never left captives alive. When Buttercup got the news that Westley was murdered --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- murdered by pirates is good --

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: She went into her room and shut the door. And for days, she neither slept nor ate.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I will never love again.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Five years later, the main square of Florin City was filled as never before to hear the announcement of the great Prince Humperdinck's bride-to be.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: -- but perhaps you will not find her common now. Would you like to meet her?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: My people ... the Princess Buttercup!!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Buttercup's emptiness consumed her. Although the law of the land gave Humperdinck the right to choose his bride, she did not love him.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Despite Humperdinck's reassurance that she would grow to love him, the only joy she found was in her daily ride.

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: A word, my lady?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: We are but poor, lost circus performers. Is there a village nearby?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: There is nothing nearby; not for miles.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Then there will be no one to hear you scream-

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: What is that you're ripping?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: It's fabric from the uniform of an Army officer of Guilder.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Who's Guilder?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Go!

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Once the horse reaches the castle, the fabric will make the Prince suspect the Guilderians have abducted his love. When he finds her body dead on the Guilder frontier, his suspicions will be totally confirmed.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You never said anything about killing anyone.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I've hired you to help me start a war. That's a prestigious line of work with a long and glorious tradition.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I just don't think it's right, killing an innocent girl.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Am I going mad or did the word "think" escape your lips? You were not hired for your brains, you hippopotamic land mass.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I agree with Fezzik.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: And remember this -- never forget this --

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: -- and you -- friendless, brainless, helpless, hopeless -- Do you want me to send you back to where you were, unemployed in Greenland?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I think he likes to scream at us.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Probably he means no harm.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: He's really very short on charm.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Oh, you've a great gift for rhyme.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Yes, some of the time.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Enough of that.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: FEZZIK, are there rocks ahead?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: If there are, we'll all be dead.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: No more rhymes now, I mean it.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Anybody want a peanut?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: We'll reach the Cliffs by dawn.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Why are you doing that?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Making sure nobody's following us.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: That would be inconceivable.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Despite what you think, you will be caught. And when you are, the Prince will see you all hanged.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Of all the necks on this boat, Highness, the one you should be worrying about is your own.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Stop doing that. We can all relax, it's almost over-

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You're sure nobody's following us?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: As I told you, it would be absolutely, totally, and in all other ways, inconceivable. No one in Guilder knows what we've done. And no one in Florin could have gotten here so fast. Out of curiosity, why do you ask?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: No reason. It's only, I just happened to look behind us, and something is there.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Probably some local fisherman out for a pleasure cruise at night through eel-infested waters.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Go in, get after her!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I don't swim.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I only dog paddle.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Veer left. Left. Left!

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Do you know what that sound is, Highness? Those are the Shrieking Eels -- if you doubt me, just wait. They always grow louder when they're about to feed on human flesh.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: If you swim back now, I promise, no harm will come to you. I doubt you will get such an offer from the Eels.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: She doesn't get eaten by the Eels at this time.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The Eel doesn't get her. I'm explaining to you because you looked nervous.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Well, I wasn't nervous.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Well, maybe I was a little bit concerned. But that's not the same thing.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Because I can stop now if you want.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: No. You could read a little bit more ... if you want.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: "Do you know what that sound is, Highness?"

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Those are the Shrieking Eels.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: We're past that, Grandpa.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You read it already.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Oh. Oh my goodness, I did. I'm sorry. Beg your pardon.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: All right, all right, let's see. Uh, she was in the water, the Eel was coming after her. She was frightened. The Eel started to charge her. And then -

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Put her down. Just put her down.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I think he's getting closer.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: He's no concern of ours. Sail on!  I suppose you think you're brave, don't you?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Only compared to some.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Look! He's right on top of us. I wonder if he is using the same wind we are using.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Whoever he is, he's too late --  The Cliffs of Insanity.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Hurry up. Move the thing! Um ... that other thing. Move it!  We're safe -- only FEZZIK is strong enough to go up our way -- he'll have to sail around for hours 'til he finds a harbor.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: He's climbing the rope. And he's gaining on us.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Inconceivable!

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Faster!

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I thought I was going faster.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: You were supposed to be this colossus. You were this great, legendary thing. And yet he gains.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Well, I'm carrying three people. And he's got only himself.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I'm just going to have to find myself a new giant, that's all.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Don't say that, Vizzini. Please.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Did I make it clear that your job is at stake?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: He has very good arms.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: He didn't fall? Inconceivable!!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: My God! He's climbing.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Whoever he is, he's obviously seen us with the Princess, and must therefore die.  We'll head straight for the Guilder frontier. Catch up when he's dead. If he falls, fine. If not, the sword.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I want to duel him left-handed.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: You know what a hurry we're in.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Well, it's the only way I can be satisfied. If I use my right -- tch -- over too quickly.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Oh, have it your way.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You be careful.  -- people in masks cannot be trusted.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I'm waiting!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Hello there.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Slow going?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I do not suppose you could speed things up?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I could do that. In fact, I've got some rope up here. But I do not think that you will accept my help, since I am only waiting around to kill you.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: But I promise I will not kill you until you reach the top.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I hate waiting. I could give you my word as a Spaniard.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You don't know any way you'll trust me?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I swear on the soul of my father, Domingo Montoya, you will reach the top alive.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We'll wait until you're ready.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I do not mean to pry, but you don't by any chance happen to have six fingers on your right hand?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: My father was slaughtered by a sixfingered man. He was a great swordmaker, my father. And when the six-fingered man appeared and requested a special sword, my father took the job. He slaved a year before he was done.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: The six-fingered man returned and demanded it, but at one-tenth his promised price. My father refused. Without a word, the six-fingered man slashed him through the heart. I loved my father, so, naturally, challenged his murderer to a duel ... I failed ...

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I was eleven years old. When I was strong enough, I dedicated my life to the study of fencing. So the next time we meet, I will not fail. I will go up to the sixfingered man and say, "Hello, my name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die."

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: More pursuit than study lately. You see, I cannot find him. It's been twenty years now. I am starting to lose confidence. I just work for Vizzini to pay the bills. There's not a lot of money in revenge.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You are ready, then?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You seem a decent fellow. I hate to kill you.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Begin!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You're using Bonetti's defense against me, ah?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Naturally, you must expect me to attack with Capo Ferro.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Unless the enemy has studied his Agrippa-

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- which I have.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You are wonderful!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I admit it -- you are better than I am.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Because I know something you don't know.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I am not left-handed.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I ought to be after twenty years.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Tell me.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Who are you?!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I must know.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Kill me quickly.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Inconceivable!

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Give her to me.  Catch up with us quickly.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: What do I do?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Finish him, finish him. Your way.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Oh, good, my way. Thank you, Vizzini.  Which way is my way?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Pick up one of those rocks, get behind the boulder, and in a few minutes, the Man in Black will come running around the bend. The minute his head is in view, hit it with the rock!

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: My way's not very sportsmanlike.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I did that on purpose. I don't have to miss.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: We face each other as God intended. Sportsmanlike. No tricks, no weapons, skill against skill alone.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I could kill you now.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: It's not my fault being the biggest and the strongest. I don't even exercise.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I just want you to feel you're doing well. I hate for people to die embarrassed.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You're quick.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Why do you wear a mask? Were you burned by acid, or something like that?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I just figured out why you give me so much trouble.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Well, I haven't fought just one person for so long. I've been specializing in groups. Battling gangs for local charities, that kind of thing.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Well ...  ... you see, you use different moves when you're fighting half a dozen people than when you only have to be worried about one.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: There was a mighty duel -- it ranged all over. They were both masters.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Who won? How did it end?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: The winner followed those footprints toward Guilder!

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Shall we track them both?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: The loser is nothing. -- Only the Princess matters --  -- clearly this was all planned by warriors of Guilder. We must be ready for whatever lies ahead.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Could this be a trap?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I always think everything could be a trap -- Which is why I'm still alive.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: So, it is down to you. And it is down to me.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: If you wish her dead, by all means keep moving forward.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: -- there's nothing to explain. You're trying to kidnap what I've rightfully stolen.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: There will be no arrangement --  -- and you're killing her!

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I'm afraid so -- I can't compete with you physically. And you're no match for my brains.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Let me put it this way: have you ever heard of Plato, Aristotle, Socrates?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Morons.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: For the Princess?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: To the death?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I accept.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I smell nothing.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Hmm.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: But it's so simple. All I have to do is divine from what I know of you. Are you the sort of man who would put the poison into his own goblet, or his enemy's?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Now, a clever man would put the poison into his own goblet, because he would know that only a great fool would reach for what he was given. I'm not a great fool, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But you must have known I was not a great fool; you would have counted on it, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Not remotely. Because iocane comes from Australia, as everyone knows. And Australia is entirely peopled with criminals. And criminals are used to having people not trust them, as you are not trusted by me. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Wait till I get going! Where was I?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Yes -- Australia, and you must have suspected I would have known the powder's origin, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: You've beaten my giant, which means you're exceptionally strong. So, you could have put the poison in your own goblet, trusting on your strength to save you. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But, you've also bested my Spaniard which means you must have studied. And in studying, you must have learned that man is mortal so you would have put the poison as far from yourself as possible, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: It has worked -- you've given everything away -- I know where the poison is.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I will. And I choose --

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: -- what in the world can that be?

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: Oh, well, I-I could have sworn I saw something. No matter.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: I'll tell you in a minute. First, let's drink -- me from my glass, and you from yours.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: -- that's what's so funny! I switched glasses when your back was turned. You fool.

Speaker: vizzini
Dialogue: You fell victim to one of the classic blunders. The most famous is "Never get involved in a land war in Asia." But only slightly less well known is this: "Never go in against a Sicilian when death is on the line."

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: To think -- all that time it was your cup that was poisoned.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Someone has beaten a giant!  There will be great suffering in Guilder if she dies.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: If you'll release me ... whatever you ask for ransom ... you'll get it, I promise you...

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I was giving you a chance. No matter where you take me ... there's no greater hunter than Prince Humperdinck. He could track a falcon on a cloudy day. He can find you

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I never said he was my dearest love. And yes, he will save me. That I know.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: He knows I do not love him.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I have loved more deeply than a killer like yourself could ever dream.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Iocane. I'd bet my life on it.  And there are the Princess's footprints. She is alive ... or was, an hour ago. If she is otherwise when I find her, I shall be very put out.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I know who you are -- your cruelty reveals everything.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You're the Dread Pirate Roberts; admit it.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You can die slowly cut into a thousand pieces.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You killed my love.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: No. A farm boy. Poor. Poor and perfect, with eyes like the sea after a storm.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: On the high seas, your ship attacked, and the Dread Pirate Roberts never takes prisoners.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You mock my pain!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Nothing you can say will upset me.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: And what am I?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You mocked me once, never do it again -- I died that day!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You can die too, for all I care!!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Oh, my sweet Westley; what have I done?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Disappeared. He must have seen us closing in, which might account for his panicking in error. Unless I'm wrong, and I am never wrong, they are headed dead into the fire swamp.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Can you move at all?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Move? You're alive. If you want, I can fly.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I told you, "I would always come for you." Why didn't you wait for me?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Well ... you were dead.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Death cannot stop true love. All it can do is delay it for a while.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I will never doubt again.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: There will never be a need.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Oh no. No, please.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: What is it? What's the matter?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: They're kissing again, do we have to hear the kissing part?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Someday, you may not mind so much.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Skip on to the Fire Swamp -- that sounded good.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Oh. You're sick, I'll humor you.  So now, where were we here? Yeah, yeah, yeah. Ah. Oh. Okay. Westley and Buttercup raced along the ravine floor.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Ha. Your pig fiance is too late. A few more steps and we'll be safe in the Fire Swamp.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: We'll never survive.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Nonsense -- you're only saying that because no one ever has.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It's not that bad. I'm not saying I'd like to build a summer home here, but the trees are actually quite lovely.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Well now, that was an adventure.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Singed a bit, were you?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Well, one thing I will say. The Fire Swamp certainly does keep you on your toes.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: This will all soon be but a happy memory because Roberts' ship "Revenge" is anchored at the far end. And I, as you know, am Roberts.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: But how is that possible, since he's been marauding twenty years and you only left me five years ago?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I myself am often surprised at life's little quirks.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: You see, what I told you before about saying "please" was true. It intrigued Roberts, as did my descriptions of your beauty.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Finally, Roberts decided something. He said, "All right, Westley, I've never had a valet. You can try it for tonight. I'll most likely kill you in the morning." Three years he said that. "Good night, Westley. Good work. Sleep well. I'll most likely kill you in the morning." It was a fine time for me. I was learning to fence, to fight, anything anyone would teach me. And Roberts and I eventually became friends. And then it happened.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: What? -- go on --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Well, Roberts had grown so rich, he wanted to retire. So he took me to his cabin and told me his secret. "I am not the Dread Pirate Roberts," he said. "My name is Ryan. I inherited this ship from the previous Dread Pirate Roberts, just as you will inherit it from me. The man I inherited it from was not the real Dread Pirate Roberts, either.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: So we sailed ashore, took on an entirely new crew and he stayed aboard for awhile as first mate, all the time calling me Roberts. Once the crew believed, he left the ship and I have been Roberts ever since. Except, now that we're together, I shall retire and hand the name over to someone else. Is everything clear to you?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: We'll never succeed -- we may as well die here.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: No. No. We have already succeeded.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I mean, what are the three terrors of the Fire Swamp? One, the flame spurts. No problem. There's a popping sound preceding each, we can avoid that. Two, the Lightning Sand. But you were clever enough to discover what that looks like, so in the future we can avoid that too.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Westley, what about the R.O.U.S.'s?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Rodents of Unusual Size? I don't think they exist...

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Westley!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: We did it.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Now, was that so terrible?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Surrender!

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: You mean you wish to surrender to me? Very well, I accept.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I give you full marks for bravery --don't make yourself a fool.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Ah, but how will you capture us? We know the secrets of the Fire Swamp. We can live there quite happily for some time. So, whenever you feel like dying, feel free to visit.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I tell you once again -- surrender!

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It will not happen!

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: For the last time -- SURRENDER!

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: DEATH FIRST!!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Will you promise not to hurt him?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: If we surrender, and I return with you, will you promise not to hurt this man?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: May I live a thousand years and never hunt again.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: He is a sailor on the pirate ship "Revenge." Promise to return him to his ship.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I swear it will be done.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Once we're out of sight, take him back to Florin and throw him in the Pit of Despair.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: I swear it will be done.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I thought you were dead once, and it almost destroyed me. I could not bear it if you died again, not when I could save you.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Come, sir. We must get you to your ship.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: We are men of action. Lies do not become us.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Well spoken, sir --

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: -- what is it?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: You have six fingers on your right hand -- someone was looking for you --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Where am I?

Speaker: albino
Dialogue: The Pit of Despair.

Speaker: albino
Dialogue: -- don't even think about trying to escape. The chains are far too thick. And don't dream of being rescued either. The only way in is secret. And only the Prince, the Count, and I know how to get in and out.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Then I'm here till I die?

Speaker: albino
Dialogue: Till they kill you. Yeah.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Then why bother curing me?

Speaker: albino
Dialogue: The Prince and the Count always insist on everyone being healthy before they're broken.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: So it's to be torture.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I can cope with torture.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: You don't believe me?

Speaker: albino
Dialogue: You survived the Fire Swamp. You must be very brave...  ... but nobody withstands The Machine.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: She's been like that ever since the Fire Swamp.  It's my father's failing health that's upsetting her.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The King died that very night, and before the following dawn, Buttercup and Humperdinck were married.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: And at noon, she met her subjects again. This time as their Queen.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: My father's final words were...

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- hold it. Hold it, Grandpa.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You read that wrong. She doesn't marry Humperdinck, she marries Westley. I'm just sure of it. After all that Westley did for her, if she does not marry him, it wouldn't be fair.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Well, who says life is fair? Where is that written? Life isn't always fair.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I'm telling you you're messing up the story, now get it right!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Do you want me to go on with this?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: All right, then. No more interruptions.  ... at noon, she met her subjects again. This time as their Queen.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: My father's final words were "love her as I loved her, and there will be joy." I present to you your Queen. Queen Buttercup.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Why do you do this?

Speaker: ancient booer
Dialogue: Because you had love in your hands, and you gave it up.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: But they would have killed Westley if I hadn't done it.

Speaker: ancient booer
Dialogue: Your true love lives and you marry another --  -- True love saved her in the Fire Swamp, and she treated it like garbage. And that's what she is, the Queen of Refuse! So, bow down to her if you want. Bow to her. Bow to the Queen of Slime, the Queen of Filth, the Queen of Putrescence. Boo! Boo! Rubbish! Filth! Slime! Muck! Boo! Boo!

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: It was ten days till the wedding. The King still lived, but Buttercup's nightmares were growing steadily worse.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: See? Didn't I tell you she'd never marry that rotten Humperdinck?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: -- yes, you're very smart. Shut-Up.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: It comes to this: I love Westley. I always have. I know now I always will. If you tell me I must marry you in ten days, please believe I will be dead by morning.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I could never cause you grief; consider our wedding off.  You returned this Westley to his ship?

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Then we will simply alert him.  Beloved, are you certain he still wants you? After all, it was you who did the leaving in the Fire Swamp. Not to mention that pirates are not known to be men of their words.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: My Westley will always come for me.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I suggest a deal. You write four copies of a letter. I'll send my four fastest ships. One in each direction. The Dread Pirate Roberts is always close to Florin this time of year. We'll run up the white flag and deliver your message. If Westley wants you, bless you both. If not ... please consider me as an alternative to suicide. Are we agreed?

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Your Princess is really a winning creature. A trifle simple, perhaps, but her appeal is undeniable.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Oh, I know. The people are quite taken with her. It's odd, but when I hired Vizzini to have her murdered on our engagement day, I thought that was clever. But it's going to be so much more moving when I strangle her on our wedding night. Once Guilder is blamed, the nation will be truly outraged. They'll demand we go to war.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Now, where is that secret knot? It's impossible to find.  Are you coming down into the Pit? Westley's got his strength back. I am starting him on The Machine tonight.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Tyrone, you know how much I love watching you work. But, I've got my country's five hundredth anniversary to plan, my wedding to arrange, My wife to murder, and Guilder to frame for it. I'm swamped.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Get some rest -- if you haven't got your health, you haven't got anything.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Beautiful, isn't it?

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: It took me half a lifetime to invent it. I'm sure you've discovered my deep and abiding interest in pain. At present I'm writing the definitive work on the subject. So I want you to be totally honest with me on how The Machine makes you feel.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: This being our first try, I'll use the lowest setting.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: As you know, the concept of the suction pump is centuries old. Well, really, that's all this is. Except that instead of sucking water, I'm sucking life. I've just sucked one year of your life away. I might one day go as high as five, but I really don't know what that would do to you. So, let's just start with what we have. What did this do to you? Tell me. And remember, this is for posterity, so be honest -- how do you feel?

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Interesting.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Yellin.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Sire.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: As Chief Enforcer of all Florin, I trust you with this secret: killers from Guilder are infiltrating the Thieves' Forest and plan to murder my bride on our wedding night.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: My spy network has heard no such news.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Any word from Westley?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Too soon, my angel. Patience.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: He will come for me.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: She will not be murdered. On the day of the wedding, I want the Thieves' Forest emptied and every inhabitant arrested.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Many of the thieves will resist. My regular enforcers will be inadequate.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Form a Brute Squad then. I want the Thieves' Forest emptied before I wed.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: It won't be easy, Sire.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Try ruling the world sometime.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: The day of the wedding arrived. The Brute Squad had their hands full carrying out Humperdinck's orders.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Is everybody out?

Speaker: assistant brute
Dialogue: Almost. There's a Spaniard giving us some trouble.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Well, you give him some trouble. Move!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I am waiting for you, Vizzini. You told me to go back to the beginning. So I have. This is where I am, and this is where I'll stay. I will not be moved.

Speaker: assistant brute
Dialogue: Ho there.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I do not budge. Keep your "Ho there."

Speaker: assistant brute
Dialogue: But the Prince gave orders --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- So did Vizzini -- when a job went wrong, you went back to the beginning. And this is where we got the job. So it's the beginning, and I'm staying till Vizzini comes.

Speaker: assistant brute
Dialogue: You! Brute! Come here.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- I -- am -- waiting -- for -- Vizzini --

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: You surely are a meanie.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: It's you.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: True!

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You don't look so good.  You don't smell so good either.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Perhaps not. I feel fine.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: FEZZIK and Inigo were reunited. And as FEZZIK nursed his inebriated friend back to health, he told Inigo of Vizzini's death and the existence of Count Rugen, the sixfingered man. Considering Inigo's lifelong search, he handled the news surprisingly well.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Fezzik took great care in reviving Inigo.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: That's enough. That's enough! Where is this Rugen so I may kill him?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: He's with the Prince in the Castle. But the castle gate is guarded by thirty men.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: How many could you handle?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I don't think more than ten.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I need Vizzini to plan. I have no gift for strategy.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: But Vizzini's dead.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: No -- not Vizzini -- I need the Man in Black --

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: -- what? --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- look, he bested you with strength, your greatness. He bested me with steel. He must have outthought Vizzini, and a man who can do that can plan my castle's onslaught any day. Let's go --

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: -- where?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: To find the Man in Black, obviously.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: But you don't know where he is.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Don't bother me with trifles; after twenty years, at last, my father's soul will be at peace.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: There will be blood tonight!!

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Rise and report.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: The Thieves' Forest is emptied. Thirty men guard the castle gate.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Double it. My Princess must be safe.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: The gate has but one key, and I carry that.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Ah! My dulcet darling. Tonight we marry. Tomorrow morning, your men will escort us to Florin Channel where every ship in my armada waits to accompany us on our honeymoon.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Every ship but your four fastest, you mean.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Every ship but the four you sent.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, of course. Naturally, not those four.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Your Majesties.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: You never sent the ships. Don't bother lying. It doesn't matter. Westley will come for me anyway.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: You're a silly girl.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Yes, I am a silly girl, for not having seen sooner that you were nothing but a coward with a heart full of fear.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I-would-not-say-such things-if- Iwere-you-

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Why not? You can't hurt me. Westley and I are joined by the bonds of love. And you cannot track that. Not with a thousand bloodhounds. And you cannot break it. Not with a thousand swords. And when I say you are a coward, that is only because you are the slimiest weakling ever to crawl the earth.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: IWOULDNOTSAYSUCHTHINGSIFIWEREYOU!

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: You truly love each other, and so you might have been truly happy. Not one couple in a century has that chance, no matter what the storybooks say. And so I think no man in a century will suffer as greatly as you will.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Not to fifty!!!

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: The Man in Black?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: His true love is marrying another tonight, so who else has cause for Ultimate Suffering?  Excuse me --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- pardon me, it's important --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- Fezzik, please --

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Everybody ... MOVE!!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Where is the Man in Black?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You get there from this grove, yes?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Fezzik, jog his memory.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Inigo. I didn't mean to jog him so hard. Inigo?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Father, I have failed you for twenty years. Now our misery can end. Somewhere ... somewhere close by is a man who can help us. I cannot find him alone. I need you. I need you to guide my sword. Please.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Guide my sword.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: He's dead.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: It just is not fair.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- Grandpa, Grandpa -- wait --

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- wait -- what did FEZZIK mean, "He's dead?" I mean he didn't mean dead.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Westley's only faking, right?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: You want me to read this or not?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Who gets Humperdinck?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Who kills Prince Humperdinck? At the end, somebody's got to do it. Is it Inigo? Who?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Nobody. Nobody kills him. He lives.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: You mean he wins? Jesus, Grandpa! What did you read me this thing for?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: You know, you've been very sick and you're taking this story very seriously. I think we better stop now.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: -- sit down. All right?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Okay.  All right, now, let's see. Where were we? Oh yes. In the Pit of Despair.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Well, we Montoyas have never taken defeat easily. Come along, Fezzik. Bring the body.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: The body?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Have you any money?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I have a little.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I just hope it's enough to buy a miracle, that's all.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: What? What?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Are you the Miracle Max who worked for the King all those years?

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: The King's stinking son fired me. And thank you so much for bringing up such a painful subject. While you're at it, why don't you give me a nice paper cut and pour lemon juice on it? We're closed!

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Beat it or I'll call the Brute Squad.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I'm on the Brute Squad.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: You are the Brute Squad.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We need a miracle. It's very important.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Look, I'm retired. And besides, why would you want someone the King's stinking son fired? I might kill whoever you wanted me to miracle.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: He's already dead.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: He is, eh? I'll take a look. Bring him in.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: I've seen worse.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Sir. Sir.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Hah?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We're really in a terrible rush.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Don't rush me, sonny. You rush a miracle man, you get rotten miracles. You got money?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Sixty-five.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Sheesh! I never worked for so little, except once, and that was a very noble cause.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: This is noble, sir.  His wife is crippled. His children are on the brink of starvation.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Are you a rotten liar.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I need him to help avenge my father, murdered these twenty years.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Your first story was better.  He probably owes you money, huh? Well, I'll ask him.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: He's dead. He can't talk.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Look who knows so much. Well, it just so happens that your friend here is only mostly dead. There's a big difference between mostly dead and all dead. Please open his mouth.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Now, mostly dead is slightly alive. Now, all dead...well, with all dead, there's usually only one thing that you can do.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Go through his clothes and look for loose change.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Hey! Hello in there. Hey! What's so important? What you got here that's worth living for?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: ... tr ... oooo .... luv...

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: True love. You heard him. You could not ask for a more noble cause than that.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Sonny, true love is the greatest thing in the world. Except for a nice MLT, a mutton, lettuce and tomato sandwich, where the mutton is nice and lean and the tomato is ripe. They're so perky, I love that. But that's not what he said. He distinctly said "to blave." And, as we all know, "to blave" means "to bluff." So you're probably playing cards, and he cheated

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: -- get back, witch --

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: I'm not a witch, I'm your wife. But after what you just said, I'm not even sure I want to be that anymore.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: You never had it so good.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: "True love." He said, "true love," Max. My God --

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Don't say another word, Valerie.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: He's afraid. Ever since Prince Humperdinck fired him, his confidence is shattered.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Why'd you say that name -- you promised me that you would never say that name --

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: What, Humperdinck? Humperdinck. Humperdinck. Ooo-ooo, Humperdinck

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: I'm not listening.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: A life expiring and you don't have the decency to say why you won't help --

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Nobody's hearing nothing!

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Humperdinck. Humperdinck! Humperdinck!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- But this is Buttercup's true love -- If you heal him, he will stop Humperdinck's wedding.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Humperdinck. Humperdinck --

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Wait. Wait. I make him better, Humperdinck suffers?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Humiliations galore!

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: That is a noble cause. Give me the sixty-five, I'm on the job.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: That's a miracle pill?

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: The chocolate coating makes it go down easier. But you have to wait fifteen minutes for full potency. And you shouldn't go swimming after, for at least, what?

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: An hour.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Yeah, an hour.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: A good hour. Yeah.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Thank you for everything.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Bye-bye, boys.

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: Have fun storming the castle.

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Think it'll work?

Speaker: miracle max
Dialogue: It would take a miracle. Bye!

Speaker: valerie
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Inigo -- there's more than thirty --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We've got him. Help me here. We'll have to force feed him.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Has it been fifteen minutes?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We can't wait -- the wedding's in half an hour and we must strike in the hustle and the bustle beforehand.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Tilt his head back. Open his mouth.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: How long do we have to wait before we know if the miracle works?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Your guess is as good as mine --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I'll beat you both apart. I'll take you both together.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Guess not very long.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Why won't my arms move?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You've been mostly dead all day.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: We had Miracle Max make a pill to bring you back.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Who are you? -- Are we enemies? Why am I on this wall? -- Where's Buttercup? --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Let me explain --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: That doesn't leave much time for dilly dallying.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You've just wiggled your finger. That's wonderful.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I've always been a quick healer.  What are our liabilities?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: There is but one working castle gate.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: And it is guarded by sixty men.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: And our assets?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Your brains, Fezzik's strength, my steel.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: That's it? Impossible. If I had a month to plan, maybe I could come up with something. But this...

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: You just shook your head -- that doesn't make you happy?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: My brains, his steel, and your strength against sixty men, and you think a little head jiggle is supposed to make me happy? I mean, if we only had a wheelbarrow, that would be something.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Where did we put that wheelbarrow the Albino had?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Over the Albino, I think.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Well, why didn't you list that among our assets in the first place? What I wouldn't give for a holocaust cloak.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: There we cannot help you.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Will this do?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Where did you get that?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: At Miracle Max's. It fit so nice, he said I could keep it.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: All right, all right. Come on, help me up.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Now, I'll need a sword eventually.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Why? You can't even lift one.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: True, but that's hardly common knowledge, is it?  Thank you. Now, there may be problems once we're inside.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I'll say -- how do I find the Count? -- Once I do, how do I find you again? -- Once I find you again, how do we escape? --

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Don't pester him, he's had a hard day.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Right, right, sorry.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Inigo.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I hope we win...

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: You don't seem excited, my little muffin.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Should I be?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Brides often are, I'm told.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I do not marry tonight.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: My Westley will save me.

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: Mawidge...mawidge is what bwings us togewer today...

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: Mawidge, the bwessed awwangement, that dweam wiffim a dweam...

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Stand your ground, men. Stand your ground.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Stand your ground.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I AM THE DREAD PIRATE ROBERTS. THERE WILL BE NO SURVIVORS.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: MY MEN ARE HERE, AND I AM HERE, BUT SOON YOU WILL NOT BE HERE

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Now?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Light him.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: THE DREAD PIRATE ROBERTS TAKES NO SURVIVORS. ALL YOUR WORST NIGHTMARES ARE ABOUT TO COME TRUE.

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: ... Ven wuv, twoo wuv, wiw fowwow you fowever..

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: THE DREAD PIRATE ROBERTS IS HERE FOR YOUR SOULS!

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Stay where you are. I said stay where you are!

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: ... so tweasuwe your vruv..

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Skip to the end.

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: Have you the wing?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Here comes my Westley now.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: FEZZIK, the portcullis.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Your Westley is dead.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I killed him myself.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Then why is there fear behind your eyes?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Give us the gate key.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: I have no gate key.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Fezzik, tear his arms off.

Speaker: yellin
Dialogue: Oh, you mean this gate key.

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: And do you, Pwincess Buwwercwup...

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Man and wife -- say man and wife...

Speaker: impressive clergyman
Dialogue: Man and wife.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: Escort the bride to the Honeymoon Suite -- I'll be there shortly.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: He didn't come.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Kill the dark one and the giant, but leave the third for questioning.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Fezzik, I need you --

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I can't leave him alone.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: He's getting away from me, Fezzik. Please. FEZZIK!

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: I'll be right back.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Thank you --

Speaker: king
Dialogue: Strange wedding.

Speaker: queen
Dialogue: Yes. A very strange wedding. Come along.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: What was that for?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Because you've always been so kind to me. And I won't be seeing you again since I'm killing myself once we reach the Honeymoon Suite.

Speaker: king
Dialogue: She kissed me...

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: ... Sorry, Father ... I tried ... I tried...

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: You must be that little Spanish brat I taught a lesson to all those years ago. It's simply incredible. Have you been chasing me your whole life only to fail now? I think that's the worst thing I ever heard. How marvelous.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: There's a shortage of perfect breasts in this world. It would be a pity to damage yours.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Oh, Westley, darling.  Westley, why won't you hold me?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Gently.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: At a time like this that's all you can think to say? "Gently?"

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Gently!!

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Good heavens. Are you still trying to win?

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: You've got an overdeveloped sense of vengeance. It's going to get you into trouble some day.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya, you killed my father; prepare to die.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya, you killed my father, prepare to die.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: Stop saying that!

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: HELLO! MY NAME IS INIGO MONTOYA. YOU KILLED MY FATHER. PREPARE TO DIE.

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: No --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- offer me money --

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: -- yes --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- power too -- promise me that --

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: -- all that I have and more please --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: -- offer me everything I ask for --

Speaker: rugen
Dialogue: -- anything you want --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: I WANT MY FATHER BACK, YOU SON- OFA-BITCH!

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Oh, Westley, will you ever forgive me?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: What hideous sin have you committed lately?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: I got married. I didn't want to. It all happened so fast.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It never happened.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It never happened.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: But it did. I was there. This old man said, "Man and wife."

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Did you say, "I do"?

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Well, no, we sort of skipped that part.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Then you're not married -- if you didn't say it, you didn't do it  -- wouldn't you agree, Your Highness?

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: A technicality that will shortly be remedied. But first things first. To the death.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: No.  To the pain.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I don't think I'm quite familiar with that phrase.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I'll explain. And I'll use small words so that you'll be sure to understand, you wart-hog-faced buffoon.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: That may be the first time in my life a man has dared insult me.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It won't be the last. To the pain means the first thing you lose will be your feet, below the ankles, then your hands at the wrists, next your nose.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: -- and then my tongue, I suppose. I killed you too quickly the last time, a mistake I don't mean to duplicate tonight.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I wasn't finished -- the next thing you lose will be your left eye, followed by your right --

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: -- and then my ears, I understand. Let's get on with it

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Wrong! Your ears you keep, and I'll tell you why --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: -- so that every shriek of every child at seeing your hideousness will be yours to cherish -- every babe that weeps at your approach, every woman who cries out, "Dear God, what is that thing?" will echo in your perfect ears.

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I think you're bluffing --

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: It's possible, pig -- I might be bluffing -- it's conceivable, you miserable vomitous mass, that I'm only lying here because I lack the strength to stand -- then again, perhaps I have the strength after all.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: DROP-YOUR-SWORD.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Have a seat.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Tie him up. Make it as tight as you like.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Where's Fezzik?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: I thought he was with you.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: In that case --

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Help him.

Speaker: buttercup
Dialogue: Why does Westley need helping?

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Because he has no strength --

Speaker: humperdinck
Dialogue: I knew it! I knew you were bluffing! I knew he was bluffing.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: Shall I dispatch him for you?

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Thank you, but no -- whatever happens to us, I want him to live a long life alone with his cowardice.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Inigo! Inigo, where are you?

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Ah, there you are. Inigo, I saw the Prince's stables, and there they were, four white horses. And I thought, there are four of us, if we ever find the lad -- hello, lad -- so I took them with me, in case we ever bumped into each other.  I guess we just did.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: FEZZIK, you did something right.

Speaker: fezzik
Dialogue: Don't worry -- I won't let it go to my head.

Speaker: inigo
Dialogue: You know, it's very strange -- I have been in the revenge business so long, now that it's over, I don't know what to do with the rest of my life.

Speaker: westley
Dialogue: Have you ever considered piracy? You'd make a wonderful Dread Pirate Roberts.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: They rode to freedom. And as dawn arose, Westley and Buttercup knew they were safe. A wave of love swept over them. And as they reached for each other...

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: What? What?

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: No, it's kissing again. You don't want to hear it.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: I don't mind so much.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Since the invention of the kiss, there have been five kisses that were rated the most passionate, the most pure. This one left them all behind. The end.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Now I think you ought to go to sleep.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: Okay. Okay. Okay. All right. So long.

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Grandpa?

Speaker: the kid
Dialogue: Maybe you could come over and read it again to me tomorrow.

Speaker: grandfather
Dialogue: As you wish...
